data.title: Editor is offset upon reaching line 10
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [Yes] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [Yes] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [Yes] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [Yes] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [Yes] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [Yes] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

Once the editor reaches line 10, there is a graphical glitch that offsets the text.

The assumption is that this is based on the length of the line number's textContent.

This is distracting when switching from tab to tab, or just programming in general.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new file (or just open a new editor tab)
2. Press enter until you hit line 10

**Expected behavior:** Editor shouldn't offset text

**Actual behavior:** Editor offsets text

### Example
(again, this is a confirmed behavior in safe mode)

![snap test artboard](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24572473/21232510/e35cbe10-c2b9-11e6-8481-8f94a4d1416c.gif)

### Versions

Latest Atom version
Latest Mac OS X version

data.title: Popular "linter" package does not show up when searching for packages
data.body:
When searching for `linter`, the core package enabling other linters does not show up. Since these packages don't appear to pull it in as a dependency (and don't bother mentioning that you even need it), this feels like an oversight. I would have expected it to be the very top result.

https://atom.io/packages/linter

data.title: Use new text-buffer version with a more efficient DisplayLayer
data.body:
Depends on https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/185. See that PR for a more thorough description.

Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8864
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/12391

This removes some restrictions that we previously enforced when editing large files; you can now use folds and soft wraps. The only feature that remains disabled for > 10MB files is syntax highlighting.

Large files also now open somewhat faster. Here are some benchmark results from Circle CI [before](https://circleci.com/gh/atom/atom/2204?utm_campaign=vcs-integration-link&utm_medium=referral&utm_source=github-build-link) and [after](https://circleci.com/gh/atom/atom/2205?utm_campaign=vcs-integration-link&utm_medium=referral&utm_source=github-build-link) this PR:

![benchmarks](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/21627661/38a798a4-d1ce-11e6-8f7c-590cb0c54dcb.png)

There are lot of noise in these results of course, but opening a 10MB file is consistently ~200ms faster.

data.title: [Feature request] - Make search non-blocking for the UI
data.body:
When running a search for a large folder with lots of sub-folders/files, the UI drags quite a bit. It's possible that search is on a non-blocking thread, but is injecting markup at a rate that's causing thrashing. Is Atom managing inserts with a virtual DOM or is it just inserting markup whenever a result is returned?

When performing a large search, it's more valuable to have a smooth interface than to have an immediate result inserted for each match.

data.title: Strange output
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

Some packages that use comand-line/terminal gets a strange output.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Get the latest atom version.
2. Install a plugin that uses the terminal, like git-control or platformio-atom-ide-terminal.
3. Open the terminal inside atom.

**Expected behavior:** A clean terminal; no pre-output.

**Actual behavior:** A strange output:
```
bash: module: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
bash: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_module'
bash: scl: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
bash: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_scl'
clear
/bin/sh: scl: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_scl'
/bin/sh: module: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_module'
/bin/sh: scl: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_scl'
/bin/sh: module: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_module'
/bin/sh: scl: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_scl'

/bin/sh: module: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_module'
```

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.9.3
Fedora 25 (Linux)

### More info
I can't reproduce the problem in safe mode because atom doesn't initialize plugins.
See this: https://github.com/platformio/platformio-atom-ide-terminal/issues/120

data.title: Search in Directory -> ENOENT: no such file or directory
data.body:
Hello Atom/Github team & other humans!

Currently i'm having the next issue:
- When I try to search any value in directory, ENOENT error produces execution stop. 
- When I search value without specifing directory, it makes search in all folders correctly.

Here is the error trace:
`task.coffee:86 ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat 'my/working/dir/�W@@�@8' Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat 'my/working/dir/�W@@�@8'
    at Error (native)
    at fs.lstatSync (fs.js:982:18)
    at Object.fs.lstatSync (ELECTRON_ASAR.js:239:16)
    at PathScanner.module.exports.PathScanner.stat (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/scandal/lib/path-scanner.js:87:17)
    at PathScanner.module.exports.PathScanner.processFile (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/scandal/lib/path-scanner.js:74:19)
    at /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/scandal/lib/path-scanner.js:51:19
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:123:15)`

Seems like encoding error, coz Atom throws this to:
`spell-check:es-es Can't load es_ES: Cannot find dictionary for es_ES.`

Currently I'm working on ElementaryOs 0.4 Loki (Ubuntu 16.04) & I've installed Atom with ".deb" package. Any suggestion? 

@50Wliu sorry, here you have it:
atom --version:
`Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
`
atom --save throws the same error.

Thanks for help!

data.title: ctrl-z doesn't undo anymore
data.body:
ctrl-z doesn't undo anymore but ctrl-y does now.
My keybindings are set to ctrl-z
![Keybindings](http://i.imgur.com/aBZdlTn.png)
My keymap file is empty.

The issue persists if I run atom in safe mode.  
I also deleted my .atom folder and the issue is still there.

I'm runnning atom on arch linux

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.4.12
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
```

Unfortunately I cannot tell you how to reproduce the issue because it was all of a sudden there (I didn't update atom, I didn't reboot my system, I was working on a project and all of a sudden ctrl-z didn't work anymore).  
In any other program ctrl-z still works so it's not a system wide problem.

data.title: RPM build does not respect existing RPM setup with custom topdir

data.title: Move package load/activation times into package metadata
data.body: This would be helpful for atom/settings-view#893.  Everything except `loadTime` and `activationTime` are available in the package's metadata, which is pretty much what the Settings View exclusively deals with.  This would prevent an extra call to `atom.packages.getLoadedPackage(name)` when we already have the rest of the package data available.  Unsure if this is a breaking change/if any packages are relying on this (why?).

data.title: Ctrl keybinding won't work on non-us-keyboards
data.body:
Ive updated to 1.12.7 and now the "**undo**"-action don't work anymore duo to a localisation conflict I guess. Im currently on a german-keyboard so the "z" and the "y" keys are interchanged. 
The strange thing is: If I just type "**z**" oder "**y**", the correct letter will be placed into the editor.
BUT: If I use **Ctrl+z**, nothing happens. The "Key Binding Resolver" shows, that I pushed "**Ctrl+y**" (which is **wrong**). Its like Atom will use a _US-Layout for shortcuts combinations including ctrl._

BTW: My OS ist Manjaro Linux with the (correct) german-keyboard layout activated.

Can anybody tell me if I did something wrong? :)

data.title: Shortcuts incorrect Keyboard layout
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [no idea...] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

After the latest update the shortcut ctrl-z does not work - instead I need to press ctrl-y on a qwertz keyboard. The letters z and y work correctly otherwise. Using an on-screen keyboard the layout seems to switch qwertz->qwety but letters still work correctly while the shortcut doesn't.

Reverting to 1.23.5 fixes the issue.

### Steps to Reproduce
On a qwertz keyboard
1. Update to Atom 1.12.7  
2. Do something
3. Press ctrl-z

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
undo...

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
literally nothing. The shortcut is mapped to ctrl-y instead.

### Versions

```shell
arctiq@arctiqpc pkg $ apm --version
(node:6770) DeprecationWarning: os.tmpDir() is deprecated. Use os.tmpdir() instead.
apm  1.14.1
npm  4.0.3
node 7.2.1
python 3.5.2
git 2.10.2
arctiq@arctiqpc pkg $ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.4.12
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
arctiq@arctiqpc pkg $ uname -a
Linux arctiqpc 4.8.13-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri Dec 9 07:24:34 CET 2016 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
OS: Arch linux

data.title: Switch to npm provided chromedriver instead of manually downloaded
data.body:
We manually download the Chromedriver using the GitHub API used for some of the Atom specs because previously that's all there was and presumably also because we only used it on the Mac.

Lately, it has been hitting the rate limit and these two conditions no longer exist so we can just install it via npm.

Update: Added a check to the build script to ensure when we update electron we don't forget to update the chromedriver as recommended by @nathansobo

data.title: Signing key changes for Windows
data.body:
Our new signing key is not yet widely used and is triggering SmartSafe warnings.

We move the new key to new environment variables that match the Mac naming so that master/dev builds continue to be signed with the new key.

The old key is now back on the original environment variables so stable and beta will continue to be signed by the old key for a while.

data.title: :arrow_up: electron-winstaller
data.body: Get's us the 1.5 version of Squirrel which includes stub for atom.exe that doesn't move (useful for pinning etc)

data.title: Indent width is set to 4 when atom is started or sometimes when file is just opened, but switching to another tab and back sets it back to 2
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

So I set my indents for my python to be tabs with width of 2.
So far it worked fine (I was on 0.9–1.2) and then I decided to update to 1.12 and boom! When I start Atom, all the tabs in the active file are 4 things wide. And some times when I open some file.
But, once I click some other tab and back, tabs are shrunk back to width of 2, as it should.

This is a little annoying.

### Steps to Reproduce

0. Set tab width for python to 2 and set it to always use tabs and never use spaces for indentation
1. Have some python file opened before closing Atom
2. Close Atom
3. Start Atom again
4. ...
5. Profit!

**Expected behavior:** tabs width to be always 2

**Actual behavior:** tabs width is 4 for a moment, then it becomes 2

### Versions

Tried with Atoms of 1.12.6, 1.12.7 and 1.13.0-beta8
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
Up-to-date Ubuntu 16.04 with Unity 7

data.title: Cannot open anything in Atom if no windows are already open
data.body:
### Description

When no windows are open I cannot open any folders or files using the File > Open menu. I have to click the Atom icon in the dock and wait for a blank new file to window open to appear before opening via the File -> open menu. I am on a late 2015 iMac running an up to date Sierra.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
Open Atom and close any windows

2. [Second Step]
With no windows open, select File > open

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Finder opens up and I can select a file / project

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Nothing. This has never worked for me.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.6
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

data.title: Portable mode enhancements
data.body:
This PR addresses a number of niggles with portable mode, namely:

1. Add macOS support - just create a .atom directory alongside Atom.app (fixes #13164)
2. Electron/Chromium userdata can now be portable (create electronUserData dir inside .atom - fixes #5502)
3. Removes the confusing `--portable` switch that didn't enable portable mode (it copied data)
4. Checks for a portable .atom folder in expected place before using ATOM_HOME (Comments in #10072)

Flight Manual needs to be updated once this is on stable.
